newsitem.title: USA: Holiday stillness seizes U.S. foreign crude market.
newsitem.headline: Holiday stillness seizes U.S. foreign crude market.

text.p: Activity in U.S. foreign crude markets for delivery into the U.S. Gulf slowed to a nearly complete halt Friday afternoon ahead of the U.S. Memorial Day holiday, traders said.
"It's pre-Memorial Day sleepiness," said one trader.

The North Sea market provided the only real fireworks, with Glencore's buying of a Brent cargo for June 9-11 loading at a rather pricey 17 cents premium to July Brent seen as possibly signaling some sort of posturing by Glencore.
"They're playing a game of some kind of game to try to firm up prices," said another trader.
Glencore is said to be just one cargo short of putting together an ultra large crude carrier (ULCC) for shipment to South Africa, traders said.
Domestically, Brent being offered into the USG was talked at a 60 cents discount to July WTI/Cushing, but only notionally, since talk was so thin.

Some traders said buyers would not likely show too much interest until the deltas soften to somewhere in the neighborhood of 80 cents below July WTI/Cushing since the domestic market is currently viewed as well supplied.

On the West African scene, a Forcados cargo for June 20-25 loading was heard done at a 22 cents premium to Dated Brent, with a European trading house doing the selling and the buyer as yet unidentified.
On the Latin American side, players said the outcome of Colombia state-owned Ecopetrol's latest tender for its coveted light sweet Cusiana would have to wait until next week.

Traders said Ecopetrol pushed the loading date back to June 22-23 after a first round of bidding for the previous June 17-18 loading window turned in bids far below the Colombian company's liking. The delay may give the pricey shipping market a chance to cool down, traders said.

In other Latin talk, a cargo of Colombian Cano Limon crude was heard offered at a $2.15 a barrel discount to July WTI/Cushing fob, but other traders thought that number awfully high. Talk was too thin to split those differences reliably.
Also, a European oil company was still reported trying to turn around a cargo of Colombian Vasconia at a $3.45 discount to July WTI/Cushing after picking it up last week at $3.60 under fob.
-- Oliver Ludwig New York Energy Desk +1 212 859 1633
